summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell, specifically concerning the number and availability of 'Highly Confidential' (HC) images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails reveal confusion and discrepancies about the count of HC materials (initially reported as ~5,500 vs. actual ~34,642) and logistical challenges in providing the defense access to review them.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell; corresponds with prosecutors about discovery deficiencies, specifically regarding access to and counts of Highly Confidential images and videos.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Prosecutor for the Southern District of New York handling the US v. Maxwell case; corresponds with defense about discovery issues and logistics for reviewing evidence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in US v. Maxwell; her defense team is seeking access to discovery materials, including HC images, for review at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

persons.name: Chris Everdell
persons.context: Part of Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team; reviewed HC images with Maxwell at the MDC in fall 2020.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Cc'd on email correspondence regarding discovery issues; part of the defense legal team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized materials; HC images and videos were recovered from his New York residence, electronic devices during his arrest, and his Virgin Islands residence.

connections.description: Menninger is the defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, advocating for her access to discovery materials.
Prosecutor and defense attorney corresponding about discovery issues and trial preparation in US v. Maxwell.
Maxwell is charged in connection with Epstein's activities; evidence seized from Epstein's properties is central to the case against her.
Both are part of Maxwell's defense team; Everdell reviewed HC materials with Maxwell at the MDC.
Pagliuca coordinates with FBI agents to manage evidence, verify counts of HC materials, and facilitate defense review.

events.title: FBI brings HC images to MDC for review
events.description: FBI agents brought a drive containing HC images from CDs to the Metropolitan Detention Center for Chris Everdell to review with Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Second FBI visit to MDC with HC images
events.description: FBI agents again brought the drive to the MDC for review of HC images with Maxwell.

events.title: Defense review of HC images at 500 Pearl
events.description: Laura Menninger reviewed approximately 5,500 HC images on two hard drives at 500 Pearl Street in New York.

events.title: Production of confidential images
events.description: The government produced confidential images to the defense in html file format.

events.title: Scheduled trial date
events.description: The trial for US v. Maxwell was scheduled for November 29, 2021.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (location where defense reviewed HC images)
Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) (where Maxwell was held and reviewed evidence)
New York, NY (Epstein's residence was searched)
Denver, CO (FBI field office where evidence was to be sent for defense review)
1 St. Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (address of Assistant U.S. Attorney)
keyFacts: A significant discrepancy exists in the count of Highly Confidential (HC) images and videos: initially reported as ~5,500, but an FBI 302 report indicates ~33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos (~34,642 total).

HC materials were recovered from two main sources: CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, and electronic devices seized during Epstein's arrest and searches of his New York and Virgin Islands residences.
The defense expressed concern that the majority of photographic materials had not been made available for review more than a year after the case began and two months before trial.
The government was arranging for hard drives containing remaining HC materials and boots (evidence items) to be sent to the FBI office in Colorado for defense review.

The Protective Order defined HC materials as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals' and required review under law enforcement supervision.
